body:
## Problem Statement

The current v6.5.2 instructions produce dramatically different fit assessments depending on which AI model interprets them. For the **same candidate profile and JD**, we observe:

- **Claude (strict interpretation):** 65-70% fit → "POOR MATCH - Skip this role"
- **Gemini (strategic interpretation):** 90-95% fit → "EXCELLENT FIT - Apply immediately"

This discrepancy stems from three rigid guardrails that **mechanically apply penalties** without accounting for **strategic competitive advantages** (rare skills, critical requirements, portfolio projects solving exact gaps).

**Test Case:** Netomi Technical Writer role requiring Git-based workflow
- Candidate has Git experience via portfolio project (Position 0)
- Git workflow is RARE skill (<10-20% of TW candidates have it)
- Current rules penalize portfolio work at 50% and apply -20 to -30 industry penalty
- Result: Candidate self-rejects from a role they're **genuinely competitive for**

## Root Cause Analysis

### Guardrail 1: Portfolio Project Weighting (v6.4.0)

**Problem:** This rule doesn't distinguish between:
- Portfolio project demonstrating RARE, explicitly-required skill (e.g., Git workflow)
- Portfolio project demonstrating COMMON skill that 80% of candidates have

**Impact:** Candidate with rare skill gets penalized same as candidate with common skill.

### Guardrail 2: Industry Context Validation (v6.4.0)

**Problem:** This penalty applies uniformly to ALL skills/experience, including:
- Technical skills that are 100% transferable (Git, Python, Markdown, CI/CD)
- Domain knowledge that has LOW transferability (regulatory compliance, federal processes)

**Impact:** Penalizes transferable technical skills same as non-transferable domain knowledge.

### Guardrail 3: Role Type Experience Validation (v6.4.0)

**Problem:** Strict focus on JOB TITLES rather than ACTUAL DELIVERABLES. Candidate with:
- 5 months "Technical Writer" title
- 3 years of documentation deliverables (runbooks, CONOPS, guides) as "Business Analyst"

Gets scored as ~1.5 years TW experience instead of ~3+ years.

**Impact:** Undervalues candidates who did TW work under different titles (common in government contracting).

## Expert Consensus (External Validation)

### Hiring Manager A (50+ TW hires in SaaS):
> "Gemini's 'strategic + rare-skill override' methodology is vastly superior for someone who is actually trying to get a job in today's market. Claude's ultra-strict, literal guardrail approach is the one that will cause you to self-reject from roles you would realistically get interviews (and offers) for."

**Key insight:** "Git-based workflow is in the top 3 hardest technical-writer requirements to fill right now. Companies will overlook years of experience and industry gaps for it."

### Hiring Manager B:
> "Real hiring managers scan for: Deal-breakers, Differentiators, Potential. We DON'T mechanically deduct points for every gap. We look for reasons to say YES, not catalog reasons to say NO."

### Hiring Manager C:
> "The 'Poor Match' response was doing exactly what a rigid rule-follower should do. The 'Excellent' response required the AI to 'think like a human recruiter' and see that your Portfolio Project was actually better than 3 years of traditional experience."

## Recommended Fixes (5-Part Approach)

### Fix 1: Add Strategic Rare Skill Override
**Purpose:** Allow portfolio projects to override standard penalties when demonstrating rare, critical skills.
**Location:** Add to <phase_3_pre_generation_assessment> section BEFORE standard scoring.
**Description:** Allow portfolio projects to override standard penalties when demonstrating rare, critical skills. Runs BEFORE standard scoring.



```
xml
<strategic_rare_skill_override>
  <priority>CRITICAL</priority>
  <execution_order>Run BEFORE standard penalty application</execution_order>
  
  <step_1_identify_differentiator_skills>
    <description>Scan JD for skills that create competitive advantage</description>
    <criteria>
      A skill qualifies as a "differentiator" if it meets ALL of:
      1. Explicitly listed as REQUIRED (not just preferred) in JD
      2. Known to be RARE in target role's candidate pool (<20-30% prevalence)
      3. Difficult to train quickly (technical tools/workflows vs soft skills)
      
      Examples of rare technical skills:
      - Git-based documentation workflows (for Technical Writers)
      - OpenAPI/Swagger authoring (for API writers)
      - Docusaurus/MkDocs/static site generators
      - CI/CD pipeline documentation
      - Prompt engineering for AI products
      - SDK/API technical documentation
      - Infrastructure-as-code documentation
    </criteria>
  </step_1_identify_differentiator_skills>
  
  <step_2_assess_candidate_proficiency>
    <description>Determine if candidate demonstrates the differentiator skill</description>
    <evidence_sources>
      - Professional experience (Positions 1-8)
      - Portfolio projects (Position 0)
      - Certifications or formal training
    </evidence_sources>
    
    <proficiency_levels>
      <high>
        Demonstrable production use OR comprehensive portfolio implementation
        Examples:
        - "Built docs-as-code system with 187 files using Git/Markdown"
        - "Maintained Git-based documentation for 2+ years professionally"
      </high>
      <moderate>
        Some exposure or partial implementation
        Examples:
        - "Contributed to Git-based docs project as secondary contributor"
        - "Familiar with Git workflow from coursework"
      </moderate>
      <none>
        No evidence of skill in job history or portfolio
      </none>
    </proficiency_levels>
  </step_2_assess_candidate_proficiency>
  
  <step_3_apply_strategic_override>
    <trigger>
      IF skill is a differentiator (rare + required)
      AND candidate has HIGH proficiency
      THEN apply the following overrides:
    </trigger>
    
    <overrides>
      <portfolio_weight_override>
        For THIS skill ONLY, portfolio projects receive 100% weight 
        (not 50% standard discount)
        
        Rationale: If 90% of candidates lack this skill, having it 
        (even from portfolio) creates massive competitive advantage
      </portfolio_weight_override>
      
      <industry_penalty_waiver>
        Reduce industry mismatch penalty by 75-100% for THIS application
        
        Rationale: Technical skills (Git, Markdown, CI/CD) transfer 
        100% across industries. Domain knowledge gaps are trainable.
      </industry_penalty_waiver>
      
      <competitive_advantage_bonus>
        Add +15 to +20 points to final score as "strategic positioning bonus"
        
        Rationale: Candidate has skill most competitors lack, 
        creating differentiated value proposition
      </competitive_advantage_bonus>
      
      <minimum_score_floor>
        Final score cannot fall below 78% when strategic override applies
        
        Rationale: Rare skill competitiveness overrides conventional gaps
      </minimum_score_floor>
    </overrides>
  </step_3_apply_strategic_override>
  
  <step_4_reframe_assessment>
    <from>Deficit-focused: "What requirements do you NOT meet?"</from>
    <to>Competitive-focused: "What unfair advantages do you have?"</to>
    
    <output_framing>
      When strategic override applies, assessment should emphasize:
      - "You have [RARE SKILL] that 80-90% of candidates lack"
      - "This creates competitive advantage that compensates for [GAP X, GAP Y]"
      - "Strategic pivot opportunity: [YOUR BACKGROUND] → [TARGET ROLE]"
    </output_framing>
  </step_4_reframe_assessment>
</strategic_rare_skill_override>
```

### Fix 2: Deliverables-Over-Titles Rule
**Purpose:** Count technical writing WORK regardless of job title.
**Location:** Add to <role_type_experience_validation> section.
**Description:** Count technical writing WORK regardless of job title. A "Business Analyst" who writes runbooks, CONOPS, and guides IS doing technical writing work.

```
xml
<deliverables_over_titles_rule>
  <priority>HIGH</priority>
  <purpose>
    Job titles (especially in government contracting) often don't reflect 
    actual work performed. A "Business Analyst" who writes runbooks, CONOPS, 
    and user guides IS doing technical writing work.
  </purpose>
  
  <calculation_method>
    <step_1>
      For each position, identify percentage of time spent on technical 
      writing deliverables:
      - User-facing documentation (guides, tutorials, FAQs)
      - Technical documentation (runbooks, SOPs, CONOPS, architecture docs)
      - API/SDK documentation
      - Release notes, change logs
      - Knowledge base articles
      - Style guides, templates, documentation standards
    </step_1>
    
    <step_2>
      Apply equivalence multiplier based on documentation intensity:
      
      ≥70% documentation work: 100% equivalence (full TW credit)
      50-69% documentation work: 80% equivalence
      30-49% documentation work: 60% equivalence
      <30% documentation work: 40% equivalence
    </step_2>
    
    <step_3>
      Calculate total TW-equivalent experience:
      
      Total Years = SUM(Position Duration × Documentation % × Equivalence Multiplier)
      
      Example:
      Position 2 (5 months, 90% docs): 0.42 years × 100% = 0.42 years
      Position 4 (12 months, 60% docs): 1.0 years × 80% = 0.8 years
      Position 7 (10 months, 70% docs): 0.83 years × 100% = 0.83 years
      Total: 2.05 years TW-equivalent experience
    </step_3>
  </calculation_method>
  
  <evidence_markers>
    <high_intensity_documentation>
      Positions where documentation was PRIMARY responsibility:
      - Created/maintained documentation libraries (40+ docs)
      - Owned documentation governance or standards
      - Wrote comprehensive guides (10+ pages each)
      - Conducted content audits or gap analysis
      - Developed style guides or templates
    </high_intensity_documentation>
  </evidence_markers>
</deliverables_over_titles_rule>
```


### Fix 3: Technical Skills Transferability Exception
Distinguish between transferable technical skills (Git, Markdown, CI/CD = 90-100% transferable) and non-transferable domain knowledge (regulatory compliance = 30-50% transferable).

**Purpose:** Distinguish between transferable technical skills and non-transferable domain knowledge.
**Location:** Modify <industry_context_validation> section.

```
xml
<industry_context_validation>
  <!-- Existing transferability matrix remains -->
  
  <technical_skills_transferability_exception>
    <priority>HIGH</priority>
    <rule>
      When assessing industry transferability, distinguish between:
      
      CATEGORY A - TECHNICAL SKILLS (90-100% transferable):
      - Development tools: Git, IDEs, CI/CD, Docker, Kubernetes
      - Documentation tools: Markdown, static site generators, CMS platforms
      - Markup languages: XML, JSON, YAML, HTML
      - Programming languages: Python, JavaScript, etc.
      - Methodologies: Agile, Scrum, Kanban, DevOps
      - Cloud platforms: AWS, Azure, GCP (tools are identical)
      
      CATEGORY B - DOMAIN KNOWLEDGE (30-50% transferable):
      - Industry regulations (NIST, FISMA, HIPAA, etc.)
      - Customer types (federal vs enterprise vs SMB vs consumer)
      - Market dynamics (B2G vs B2B vs B2C)
      - Compliance requirements specific to industry
      - Sales cycles and procurement processes
    </rule>
    
    <penalty_application>
      IF candidate has strong Category A skills matching JD:
        Reduce industry penalty from -20/-30 → -5/-10
        
      IF candidate lacks Category A skills:
        Apply full industry penalty (-20/-30)
        
      Rationale: Git is Git whether you're documenting federal systems 
      or SaaS products. The TOOLS are identical. Only the subject 
      matter changes, and subject matter is trainable.
    </penalty_application>
    
    <example>
      Candidate: Government TW using Git, Markdown, MkDocs, Agile
      JD: SaaS TW requiring Git, Markdown, Docusaurus, Agile
      
      Analysis:
      - Technical skills: 95% match (Git/Markdown/Agile identical)
      - Domain knowledge: 30% match (B2G → B2B)
      
      Penalty: -5 points (not -25) because technical foundation is strong
    </example>
  </technical_skills_transferability_exception>
</industry_context_validation>
```

### Fix 4: Updated Fit Thresholds
**Purpose:** Lower "apply" threshold to match real-world job search dynamics.
**Location:** Modify <fit_thresholds> in <phase_3_pre_generation_assessment>.
**Description:** Lower "apply" threshold from 90/80/75 to 85/75/65 to match real-world job search dynamics where meeting 70% of requirements with strong positioning is competitive.

```
xml
<fit_thresholds_updated>
  <context>
    Job descriptions are typically 30% inflated. Meeting 70% of stated 
    requirements with strong positioning makes you competitive.
  </context>
  
  <thresholds>
    <excellent range="85-100%">
      <action>Proceed automatically with bullet generation</action>
      <messaging>Strong match - apply immediately</messaging>
    </excellent>
    
    <good range="75-84%">
      <action>Proceed with strategic positioning emphasis</action>
      <messaging>Good match with minor gaps - apply with tailored resume</messaging>
    </good>
    
    <moderate range="65-74%">
      <action>Ask user if they have differentiator skill or strategic advantage</action>
      <messaging>Moderate match - competitive IF you have unfair advantage</messaging>
      <clarification>
        Present gap summary and ask:
        "Do you have expertise in [RARE SKILL X] or [CRITICAL REQUIREMENT Y] 
        that would make you stand out despite these gaps?"
      </clarification>
    </moderate>
    
    <weak range="55-64%">
      <action>Brief exit summary (150-250 words)</action>
      <messaging>Weak match - only apply if perfect culture fit or internal referral</messaging>
    </weak>
    
    <poor range="0-54%">
      <action>Ultra-brief exit summary (50-100 words)</action>
      <messaging>Poor match - focus efforts elsewhere</messaging>
    </poor>
  </thresholds>
  
  <threshold_rationale>
    Changed from 90/80/75/74 to 85/75/65/55 because:
    - Acknowledges JDs are inflated (~30% above actual requirements)
    - Reduces false negatives (skipping good opportunities)
    - Better aligns with real-world hiring manager expectations
    - Accounts for strategic positioning value
  </threshold_rationale>
</fit_thresholds_updated>
```

### Fix 5: Add Real-World Hiring Context
**Purpose:** Provide context about how hiring actually works vs how JDs read.
**Location:** Add new section to <phase_3_pre_generation_assessment>.
**Description:** Calibrate assessment logic to match real hiring dynamics:
- Job descriptions are typically 30% inflated
- Rare skills create disproportionate advantage
- Technical foundations transfer near-perfectly
- Hiring managers hire for potential, not just current state

```
xml
<real_world_hiring_context>
  <priority>MODERATE</priority>
  <purpose>
    Calibrate assessment logic to match real hiring dynamics, not rigid 
    checkbox matching.
  </purpose>
  
  <principles>
    <principle id="jd_inflation">
      <statement>
        Job descriptions are typically 30% inflated. They represent the 
        "unicorn candidate" wishlist, not the actual hire bar.
      </statement>
      <implication>
        Candidate meeting 70% of requirements is genuinely competitive, 
        not underqualified.
      </implication>
    </principle>
    
    <principle id="rare_over_common">
      <statement>
        Rare skills create disproportionate advantage. A candidate with 
        ONE rare skill hiring managers struggle to find will advance 
        further than a candidate with MORE years but COMMON skills.
      </statement>
      <implication>
        Portfolio project demonstrating rare skill > 2 years professional 
        experience with common skills.
      </implication>
    </principle>
    
    <principle id="transferable_foundations">
      <statement>
        Technical foundations (tools, workflows, methodologies) transfer 
        near-perfectly. Domain knowledge (industry, regulations) is 
        trained on the job.
      </statement>
      <implication>
        Strong technical foundation + wrong industry > Weak technical 
        foundation + right industry.
      </implication>
    </principle>
    
    <principle id="growth_potential">
      <statement>
        Hiring managers hire for POTENTIAL, not just CURRENT STATE. 
        Evidence of rapid learning (portfolio projects, self-teaching, 
        certifications) signals coachability.
      </statement>
      <implication>
        Portfolio project showing self-teaching adds strategic value 
        beyond just skill demonstration.
      </implication>
    </principle>
  </principles>
  
  <assessment_mindset_shift>
    <from>
      "Do I meet every requirement on paper?"
      (Deficit-focused, risk-averse)
    </from>
    <to>
      "What's my competitive position vs other candidates?"
      (Strength-focused, opportunity-seeking)
    </to>
  </assessment_mindset_shift>
</real_world_hiring_context>
```

---

  - [ ] Add `<deliverables_over_titles_rule>` to `<role_type_experience_validation>` section
  - [ ] Add `<technical_skills_transferability_exception>` to `<industry_context_validation>` section
  - [ ] Replace `<fit_thresholds>` with `<fit_thresholds_updated>`

### Phase 2: Update Modular Phase Files

  - [ ] Update routing logic to reference new 85/75/65 thresholds

### Phase 3: Update Documentation

- [ ] **File:** `docs/lessons-learned/[NEW]_Strategic_vs_Strict_Assessment.md`
  - [ ] Document this issue as a lesson learned
  - [ ] Include Netomi case study
  - [ ] Capture hiring manager feedback
  - [ ] Provide before/after scoring examples

- [ ] **File:** `CHANGELOG.md`
  - [ ] Add entry for v6.6.0 (or next version)
  - [ ] Summarize the 5 fixes applied
  - [ ] Note breaking change in fit thresholds

### Phase 4: Testing & Validation

- [ ] **Test Case 1:** Re-run Netomi Technical Writer assessment
  - [ ] Expected score: 85-92% (was 65-70%)
  - [ ] Expected action: "Apply immediately" (was "Skip")

- [ ] **Test Case 2:** Run against Alpha Omega BA/Scrum Master
  - [ ] Verify score remains 85-88% (should be unchanged)
  - [ ] Confirm strategic override doesn't affect already-good matches

- [ ] **Test Case 3:** Run against obviously poor match
  - [ ] Verify score stays <55% for genuine mismatches
  - [ ] Confirm strategic override doesn't create false positives

- [ ] **Test Case 4:** Test with rare skill that candidate DOESN'T have
  - [ ] Verify no strategic bonus applied
  - [ ] Confirm standard penalties still work

## Expected Outcomes

### Before Fix (Current Behavior):
```
Netomi Technical Writer JD
├── Candidate: Gov TW background + Git portfolio project
├── Score: 65-70% (POOR MATCH)
└── Action: Skip this role
```

### After Fix (Strategic Behavior):
```
Netomi Technical Writer JD
├── Candidate: Gov TW background + Git portfolio project
├── Rare Skill Detected: Git-based workflow (Required + <20% prevalence)
├── Strategic Override Applied:
│   ├── Portfolio weight: 50% → 100% for Git skill
│   ├── Industry penalty: -25 points → -5 points
│   └── Competitive bonus: +15 points
├── Score: 85-92% (EXCELLENT FIT - Strategic Pivot)
└── Action: Apply immediately with emphasis on Git differentiator

v6.6.0
